thread.title: Brisbane Racing Club springs into action on $850M Ascot residential redevelopment project
thread.title_full: Brisbane Racing Club springs into action on $850M Ascot residential redevelopment project

author: Sophie Foster
title: Brisbane Racing Club springs into action on $850M Ascot residential redevelopment project
text:
AN $850 million residential development that’s expected to secure the future of blue chip Brisbane suburb Ascot is step closer to groundbreaking.
Brisbane Racing Club this morning announced it had chosen national property development group Mirvac to partner the club in a massive revamp of the historic racecourse area and its residential offerings.
Three developers were in the running for the Eagle Farm Residential Precinct project, which was expected to see “significant urban regeneration” of the area.
Eagle Farm residential precinct will be alongside the Ascot racecourse, about six kilometres from the Brisbane CBD. Source: Supplied
The development precinct covers 54,000 square metres alongside Eagle Farm racecourse, located six kilometres outside Brisbane’s CBD.
The contract involves Mirvac delivering the $850M residential precinct which combines horse racing with “Brisbane’s newest destination for food, retail and lush public parkland”.
Brisbane Racing Club chairman Neville Bell was confident the development would keep the racecourse as the Queensland epicentre of thoroughbred racing and breathe new life into the area.
“We are pleased to welcome them to this exciting venture,” he said of Mirvac. Eagle Farm has thrown some of the best parties over the years, with Fashions of the Field generating a buzz for patrons such as 2011’s Melbourne Cup Day winners Stephanie Nasternak from Mt Cotton, Alyse-Grace Robertson from Bulimba and Sally Forman from New Farm. Source: News Limited
Mirvac Head of Residential, John Carfi, said the project would “assure Ascot’s future”.
“The ambitious master plan will seamlessly integrate both the past and future into a vibrant new destination that will be loved by locals and visitors alike,” he said in a statement.
“Mirvac will draw on its 43 years of industry expertise and enviable track record in residential and commercial development to create a precinct that will benefit Brisbane residents for generations to come.”
Originally published as $850M Ascot redevelopment
